newsitem.title: JAPAN: FOCUS-Japan oil data shows impact of deregulation.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Japan oil data shows impact of deregulation.

text.p: A slew of Japanese energy data covering 1996 shows that deregulation has started to change the shape of the country's oil trade, oil industry sources said on Wednesday.
Refinery output fell for the first time in nine years in 1996, while imports of key products like kerosene and gas oil jumped sharply -- prompting a fall in crude imports.
Japan's 1996 crude oil imports totalled 263.5 million kilolitres (kl), down 1.3 percent from 1995, data Tuesday from Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) said.
"The fall in crude oil imports can be partly attributed to a rise in imports of oil products such as kerosene and gas oil," Takashi Kawai, analyst with Nikko Research Centre said.
"Some refiners also required less crude because they kept runs low in order to keep stockpiles tight and cut costs."
Japan last April removed restrictions on oil product imports, allowing companies other than oil refiners to import.
Refiners, now exposed to competition from imported products, have been striving to cut costs.
"With South Korea's oil product export capacity growing, Japan is expected to come under increasing pressure from imports this year and in 1998," Kawai said.
Japanese kerosene imports last year rose 130.9 percent to 4.4 million kl, while gas oil imports grew 40.6 percent to 1.9 million kl, according to MITI.
But 1996 output of oil products fell 0.9 percent to 225.4 million kl from a year earlier, the first drop in nine years, MITI said.
Another reason behind the fall in crude imports was weaker demand from electricity utilities, sources said.
"Crude demand from electricity utilities fell sharply last year because the summer was cooler compared to 1995, when temperatures soared," an oil industry official said.
In addition to lower temperatures denting appetite, electricity utilities are trying to cut down usage of crude and C-type fuel oil, which they use for direct burning.

Japan's largest electricity utility, Tokyo Electric Power Co (TEPCO) said last April, that it planned to slash its crude oil and fuel oil C purchases by one third in fiscal 1996/97, ending March 31, to 6.5 million kl.
Instead, TEPCO said it planned to boost operations of cheaper nuclear and liquefied natural gas (LNG) power generators.
"The drop in regional crude imports shows utilities burned less crude," the oil industry official said.
Crudes from South East Asian countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia and Vietnam are suited for direct burning because of their low-sulphur content.
MITI statistics show 1996 crude imports from Southeast Asia fell by 22 percent from the previous year to 30.6 million kl.
In contrast, imports from Nigeria grew a sharp 28.5 percent to 1.2 million kl as West African crude became more price competitive with regional and Middle East grades.
"Spot market premiums of Middle Eastern crudes were high last year and supplies of regional crudes tight, making West African crudes economic," an oil company official said.

"It is unlikely West Africa will become a major supplier to Japan because of geographical distance," said an analyst who declined to named. "However, supplies will flow into Japan when the economics work."
In the long term, exports of South East Asian crudes would fall as reserves shrink and domestic demand grows, leading to greater dependency on other regions, including the Middle East.
MITI statistics show crude imports from the Middle East in 1996 totalled 211 million kl, up 0.4 percent from a year earlier, and accounted for 80 percent of total imports.
--Tokyo Newsroom (+813 5473 3708)
